metadata.case_name: Official Assignee, High Court, Bombay v. Respondents (firm T.A. Doshi creditors)

facts.text: On January 25, 1950, a petition (I.P. No. 2 of 1950) was presented in District Court, Bellary, by some creditors of the firm T.A. Doshi, Bombay (the firm) for adjudicating the firm as insolvent.

Pending adjudication in Bellary, the District Court appointed Official Receiver as interim Receiver at instance of petitioning creditors; Receiver authorised to take possession of certain goods of insolvent in transit to Bombay, took possession, disposed of them under court orders, and deposited sale-proceeds in court.

Respondents claimed entitlement to part of deposited money as Railway Receipt for goods sold was made over to them by insolvent for consideration; they borrowed from bank on its security and faced repayment demand after seizure.

District Court allowed respondents' application; permitted withdrawal of amount on giving security and undertaking to redeposit with 6% interest when called upon; respondents withdrew on April 6, 1950. Claim remains untried.
On April 14, 1950, similar insolvency petition (I.P. No. 52 of 1950) filed against firm by other creditors on original side of Bombay High Court.
Bombay High Court passed adjudication order on April 17, 1950; all properties of insolvent vested in Official Assignee of Bombay.
Official Assignee moved District Court, Bellary (I.A. No. 183 of 1950) to stay proceedings there and transfer assets, books to Bombay; respondents made parties.

On December 13, 1950, Bellary District Court passed adjudication order and on Official Assignee's application: directed its Official Receiver to move Bombay HC to annul its April 17, 1950 order; status quo pending; if Bombay decides for administration there, hand over assets to Official Assignee.
Respondents preferred appeal against December 13, 1950 order of Bellary Court.
Official Receiver took no action on direction to move Bombay HC for long time.
Official Receiver moved Bombay HC for annulment; Bombay HC declined, directed continuance as estate more conveniently administered in Bombay.

On October 15, 1951, Official Assignee filed I.A. No. 171 of 1951 in Bellary Court noting non-compliance, seeking direction to respondents to deposit withdrawn amounts with interest, transfer sums, assets, books, file to Bombay.

Bellary Court, apprised of Bombay HC refusal to annul, allowed Official Assignee's application: directed Official Receiver to transmit accounts/deposits; respondents to refund withdrawn amounts with 6% interest for transfer to Bombay.

Respondents appealed Bellary Court's order to Andhra High Court at Guntur (Appeal against order No. 94 of 1952); High Court allowed appeal, held Official Assignee's application did not satisfy s.77 Provincial Insolvency Act, more convenient to administer at Kurnool District Court post-reorganisation.

legal_issues.text: In whom does the property of the insolvent vest: Official Assignee (Bombay High Court under Presidency Act) or Official Receiver (Bellary District Court under Provincial Act), considering dates of adjudication and relation back provisions?
Whether Official Assignee's application (I.A. 171/1951) satisfied requirements of s.77 Provincial Insolvency Act for transfer of assets, or required formal request from Bombay High Court?
Whether Bellary Court's December 13, 1950 order was final and operative post Bombay HC's refusal to annul.

petitioner_arguments.text: Property vested in Official Assignee upon Bombay HC adjudication on April 17, 1950 (relating back to March 14, 1950 per s.51 Presidency Act); Bellary adjudication on Dec 13, 1950 cannot divest it via relation back to Jan 25, 1950 (s.28(7) Provincial Act), as vesting under s.17 Presidency Act is statutory and prior.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Presidency Towns Insolvency Act ss.17, 51; Provincial Insolvency Act ss.28(2), 28(7)

petitioner_arguments.text: Official Assignee's I.A. 171/1951 not under s.77 but enforcing Bellary's own Dec 13, 1950 order (non-complied by Receiver); post Bombay refusal to annul, order fully operative directing transfer.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Provincial Insolvency Act s.77; res judicata

respondent_arguments.text: Official Assignee's application did not meet s.77 requirements (no request from Bombay HC); more convenient to administer estate at Kurnool/Bellary.
Though Bombay HC principal court, subsidiary claim re Railway Receipt can be tried at Bellary for convenience.

court_reasoning.text: Property vests in Official Assignee on making of adjudication order (s.17 Presidency Act); Bellary's later order cannot divest via relation back (s.28(7) Provincial Act has no divesting provision); relation back aids recovery from third parties, not divesting prior vesting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vesting under s.17 is statutory; no purpose in divesting for creditor protection.

court_reasoning.text: s.77 requires court-to-court request, not officer's application; but here Official Assignee enforced Bellary's own Dec 13, 1950 order (final, res judicata, parties included), fully operative post Bombay refusal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Application corollary to earlier order; s.77 not applicable.

court_reasoning.text: Bellary Dec 13 order final; Bombay principal court for entire proceedings, but liberty to respondents to seek trial of their claim there for convenience.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No opinion on subsidiary trial venue; remit to Bombay HC discretion.

holdings.text: Insolvent's property validly vested in Official Assignee, Bombay; not divested by later Bellary adjudication.
Bellary District Court order directing transfer restored; s.77 inapplicable as enforcing own prior final order.
Respondents liberty to apply to Bombay HC within 2 months for their claim trial at Bellary; else redeposit and transfer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Assignee of Madras v. Official Assignee of Rangoon by his Agent Subramania Aiyar
precedents_cited.relevance: Prior adjudication vests property in that court's Official Assignee; later adjudication (even on earlier acts) does not divest.
s.77 requires formal court request/letter, not officer's application.

statutes_cited.name: Presidency Towns Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.17: vesting on adjudication; s.51: relation back to act of insolvency; s.126: courts auxiliary like s.77.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.28(2): vesting on adjudication; s.28(7): relation back to petition date; s.77: courts auxiliary via formal request.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Andhra High Court order set aside; Bellary District Court order restored with modification giving respondents liberty to apply to Bombay HC within 2 months for trial of their claim at Bellary, else redeposit withdrawn amount with interest for transfer to Bombay.
outcome.relief_granted: Transfer of assets/books to Bombay Official Assignee; conditional liberty on respondents' claim.

key_quotes.text: "the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee by virtue of the operation of s. 17 of the Presidency Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on priority of vesting.

key_quotes.text: "the doctrine of relating back ... could have no application in the present case because the vesting in the Official Assignee is the result of a statutory provision"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why relation back does not divest prior vesting.

key_quotes.text: "the order passed by the District Court directing the transfer ... was, in a sense, a corollary to the earlier order passed by it on December 13, 1950."
key_quotes.speaker: court
